metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: Dataset of hydrometeorological observation network (an automatic weather station of Sidaoqiao mixed forest station, 2016)
metadata.description:
This data set contains meteorological element observation data from January 1, 2016 to December 31, 2016 at the downstream mixed forest station of heihe hydrometeorological observation network.The station is located at sidao bridge, dalaihubu town, ejin banner, Inner Mongolia.The longitude and latitude of the observation point are 101.1335e, 41.9903n and 874m above sea level.The air temperature and relative humidity sensors are located at 28m, facing due north.The barometer is installed in the anti-skid box on the ground;Tilting bucket rain gauge installed at 28m;The wind speed and direction sensor is located at 28m, facing due north.The four-component radiometer is installed at 24m, facing due south;Two infrared thermometers are installed at 24m, facing due south and the probe facing vertically downward.Two photosynthetically active radiators were installed at a position of 24m, facing due south, with one probe vertically upward and one probe vertically downward.The soil temperature probe is buried at 0cm of the surface and 2cm, 4cm, 10cm, 20cm, 40cm, 60cm and 100cm underground (observation at depths of 160cm,200cm and 240cm were increased on April 22), 2m to the south of the meteorological tower.The soil water probe was buried 2cm, 4cm, 10cm, 20cm, 40cm, 60cm and 100cm underground (observation at depths of 160cm,200cm and 240cm were increased on April 22), 2m to the south of the meteorological tower.The soil heat flow plates (3 pieces) are buried in the ground 6cm underground, 2m to the south of the meteorological tower.
Observation items are: air temperature and humidity (Ta_28m, RH_28m) (unit: c, percentage), pressure (Press) (unit: hundred mpa), precipitation (Rain) (unit: mm), wind speed (WS_28m) (unit: m/s), wind (WD_28m) (unit: degrees), the radiation of four component (DR, UR, DLR_Cor, ULR_Cor, Rn) (unit: watts per square meter), the surface radiation temperature (IRT_1, IRT_2) (unit:C), soil heat flux (Gs_1, Gs_2, Gs_3) (in watts/m2), soil temperature (Ts_0cm, Ts_2cm, Ts_4cm, Ts_10cm, Ts_20cm, Ts_40cm, Ts_60cm, Ts_100cm, Ts_160cm, Ts_200cm, Ts_240cm) (in:C), soil moisture (Ms_2cm, Ms_4cm, Ms_10cm, Ms_20cm, Ms_40cm, Ms_60cm, Ms_100cm, Ms_160cm, Ms_200cm, Ms_240cm) (unit: volumetric water content, percentage), upward and downward photosynthetically active radiation (PAR_up, PAR_down) (unit: micromole/sq.s).
Processing and quality control of observed data :(1) ensure 144 pieces of data every day (every 10min), and mark by -6999 in case of data missing;Due to the sensor problem, the wind direction was partly missing between April and April 21, 2016;The soil heat flux G1 is between 2.21-3.15, G2 is between 1.24-3.15, 4.4-4.22 and 12.1-12.21.(2) excluding the time with duplicate records;(3) data that obviously exceeds the physical significance or the range of the instrument is deleted;(4) the part marked with red letter in the data is the data in question;(5) date and time have the same format, and date and time are in the same column.For example, the time is: 2016-9-1010:30;(6) the naming rule is: AWS+ site name.
For information of hydrometeorological network or station, please refer to Li et al. (2013), and for observation data processing, please refer to Liu et al. (2011).

background: The two-source energy balance (TSEB) model was successfully applied to estimate evaporation (E), transpiration (T), and evapotranspiration (ET) for land covered with vegetation, which has significantly important applications for the terrestrial water cycle and water resource management. One-source evapotranspiration estimation models combine the soil–vegetation components into a single source. However, in real landscape conditions, the surface is heterogeneous and contains a mixture of soil and vegetation having different temperatures and resistance to energy exchange. Therefore, one-source models explicitly cannot estimate the surface evapotranspiration accurately because the effect of.

Shuttleworth and Wallace proposed a typical two-source evapotranspiration estimation model in which the energy partition is assumed to occur in both “the above canopy” and “the under soil” cases. Water vapor and heat meet over the reference height in the interior of the canopy. Moreover, the mixed water vapor and heat can only exit through the top of the canopy; the total heat flux is in addition to the fluxes coming from every surface layer. However, the model is complex, having over five resistances that cannot be accurately calculated. In addition, the model includes required parameters and observations that cannot be readily obtained from operational satellite- and ground-based data; therefore, the range of applications of the model is limited.

The TSEB model has undergone several revisions, improving the estimation of soil and canopy net radiation, the aerodynamic resistance of the soil surface, the fractional vegetation coverage observed at the radiometer view angle, the distribution of regional-scale near-surface air temperature, and soil and canopy component temperatures. Because the TSEB model only requires the surface energy balance model with a single measurement of land surface temperature, the original model and subsequent refinements have been widely used to estimate E and T under a wide variety of vegetation types, vegetation coverage, climates, and spatial scales. However, most studies have only evaluated the total fluxes or ET (soil plus canopy) in comparison with measurements using the Bowen ratio–energy balance system, the eddy covariance (EC) system, or the large aperture scintillometer.

Accurately estimating surface fluxes in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area is a particularly challenging task and is even more difficult when the EC flux measurements of H and LE have an incomplete energy balance closure with respect to the available energy Rn−G0. The previous sensitivity studies found that the TSEB model performance is mainly affected by the uncertainty in surface–air temperature difference. Sometimes, this difference is dominant due to the errors in determining the surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from the surface composite radiometric temperature. In this letter, it is shown that there is an overestimation of the component temperatures compared with the observed composite radiometric. This often leads to the most crucial effect on the TSEB model performance. In addition, another factor is the strong advective environment in this region.
research objective: In this letter, the ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures were used to estimate E, T, and ET, which were better validated with observed ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes, and the ET measurements using an eddy covariance (EC) system.

The objective of this letter is to estimate E, T, and ET using the soil and canopy component temperatures observed via a high-resolution thermal camera as inputs to a series TSEB model and to subsequently better validate E, T, and ET using a combination of the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope technique and EC measurements.
challenges: However, the current composite temperature separation approaches are limited in their effectiveness in arid regions. Moreover, E and T are difficult to measure on the ground.

Errors in the derived component temperature were primarily caused by image classification errors; these classification errors varied with vegetation abundance. The higher uncertainty of H estimation is not only caused by the uncertainty of the TSEB model but also due to the increased uncertainty of the EC system, which is 18% when the mean H is small in the irrigated farmland. Due to image pixel classification errors, soil pixels were counted as vegetation pixels, which produced an overestimation of the canopy temperature under the developing vegetation abundance. Alternatively, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance could have produced the uncertainties in the estimated temperatures. In addition, the estimated uncertainty of the incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy may be another source of Rn estimation errors.
methods: In this letter, the field observations were obtained from the Daman superstation installed in the central oasis, which is a 40-m boundary layer tower located at 100.3722° E, 38.8555° N and at an elevation of 1556 m. The meteorological parameters were measured every 10 min and included air temperature, wind speed, humidity at 5 m over the ground, four-component radiations (measured at 12 m above the ground using a four-component radiometer), and turbulent fluxes (measured at 4.5 m above the ground using an EC system with a sampling frequency of 10 Hz). The soil heat fluxes were measured using three heat plates located 6 cm under the ground. A Fluke Ti55 thermal infrared camera was manually operated on a 25-m-high platform on a boundary layer tower to measure the thermal radiation of the cropland approximately every 120 min; the observations were collected as thermal images from approximately 07:00 to 19:00 China Standard Time (CST) during the daytime. The ground-based measurement data were applied to partition ET into E and T applying the Craig–Gordon model.

To evaluate the TSEB model accurately, the soil heat flux was using the ground measurement. In addition, the soil and canopy sensible heat fluxes were estimated using the series TSEB model, and their latent heat fluxes were calculated while solving the energy balance equations (1) and (2), respectively. The soil and canopy component temperatures were calculated using the images obtained with the thermal camera. To calculate the component temperatures, the visible and NIR images were classified into soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method. Next, the soil and canopy directional brightness temperatures were exacted from the thermal images. Finally, the thermal infrared temperatures were converted to the radiation temperatures using the incoming long-wave radiation from the sky and the soil and canopy emissivities. Next, the simulated radiometric temperatures were validated against the surface radiometric temperatures, which were calculated according to the incoming long-wave radiation observed by the four-component radiometer.
dataset: The experimental area is an artificial oasis that is covered with maize, vegetables, and orchards. Data of day of year (DOY) 170, 173, 176, 192, 195, 231, 252, and 256 were used to determine ET and the ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) to ET during the Multi-Scale Observation Experiment on Evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces, which was part of the Heihe Water Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER-MUSOEXE).
findings: Our results indicated that even under the strongly advective conditions, the TSEB model produced reliable estimates of the E/ET% and T/ET% ratios and of ET. The mean bias and root-mean-square error (RMSE) of E/ET% were 1% and 2%, respectively, and the mean bias and RMSE of T/ET% were −1% and 2%, respectively. In addition, the model exhibited relatively reliable estimates in the latent heat flux, with mean bias and RMSE values of 31 and 61 W·m−2, respectively, compared with the measurements from the EC system. These results demonstrated that a robust soil and vegetation component temperature calculation was crucial for estimating E, T, and ET. Moreover, the separate validation of E/ET% and T/ET% provides a good prospect for TSEB model improvements.

Our results demonstrated that the TSEB model using soil and canopy component radiometric temperatures, which were obtained from a high-precision thermal infrared camera, can be applied in a strongly advection-irrigated agricultural area. Notably, the results illustrated that the latent fluxes of the soil and vegetation components were successfully separated with reasonable accuracy, as assessed using ground-based measurements. The estimated E/ET% and E/ET% values agreed well with the values observed using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes technique during the early, middle, and late growing seasons. In addition, the TSEB model produced reliable estimations of Rn, H, and LE; the mean biases of Rn, H, and LE were −18, 5, and 31 W ·m−2, respectively, and the RMSEs of Rn, H, and LE were 29, 19, and 61 W · m−2, respectively. This finding suggests that given accurate soil and vegetation component temperatures, E and T can be accurately separated from ET using the TSEB model.

background: Upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is a grand challenge. Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. HiWATER is an experiment designed to address this challenge through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.
challenges: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations.
methods: Several intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out during HiWATER. Only data collected during the IOP in 2012 are presented in this paper. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. We established a sparse network to investigate the oasis-desert interaction. One superstation was constructed within the oasis, and four EC towers and four two-layer automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) were installed in different landscapes surrounding the oasis, including sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland. Intensive observations were implemented at the irrigation district scale. A total of 12 airborne remote sensing missions were conducted to cover the FEA using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer.
dataset: We introduce a multiscale dataset obtained from Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) in an oasis-desert area in 2012. The HiWATER observation system consists of a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations; an eco-hydrological sensor network of soil moisture and leaf area index; hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer; and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes. All observational data were carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. The data are freely available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Definition.Question: What is a 'hydrometeorological observation network' in the context of eco-hydrological research?
Definition.Answer: A hydrometeorological observation network in the context of eco-hydrological research refers to a system designed to collect meteorological and hydrological data over a specific area. It typically includes various sensors and instruments such as automatic meteorological stations, eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and eco-hydrological sensors. These are used to capture data on air temperature, humidity, wind speed, radiation, soil moisture, and other parameters to study water and energy exchanges in ecosystems.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods of the Daman superstation compare to those employed in the oasis-desert system for capturing eco-hydrological processes?
Comparison.Answer: The Daman superstation uses a boundary layer tower equipped with eddy covariance systems and a variety of sensors to measure meteorological and turbulent flux parameters, while the oasis-desert system employs a network of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations arranged in hierarchically nested scales. The oasis-desert system also integrates remote sensing technologies like LiDAR and imaging spectrometry to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes.

Comparison.Question: What are the similarities and differences in data quality control processes between the observational datasets for the oasis–desert system and the hydrometeorological observations from the mixed forest station?
Comparison.Answer: Both datasets emphasize rigorous quality control, including sensor calibration and data processing. The oasis–desert system data undergoes quality control throughout the data lifecycle, from sensor calibration to dataset generation, while the mixed forest station data handling includes steps like removing duplicate records and marking dubious data points, with a focus on maintaining consistent date and time formats.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the challenges of estimating evapotranspiration in a strongly advective agricultural area compare to the challenges faced in observing eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert systems?
Comparison.Answer: Both scenarios deal with challenges of heterogeneity and complex environmental interactions. In the strongly advective agricultural area, the challenges include uncertainties in surface-air temperature differences and component temperature classifications. In the oasis-desert systems, the primary challenge is the poor availability of multiscale observations to upscale eco-hydrological processes. Both require reliable ground-based and remote sensing data to improve model accuracy and process understanding.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in accurately estimating surface fluxes in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Accurately estimating surface fluxes in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas is challenging due to the incomplete energy balance closure with respect to the available energy Rn−G0, the uncertainty in surface–air temperature difference, and errors in determining the surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from the surface composite radiometric temperature.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is the availability of multiscale observations limited in the context of upscaling eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The availability of multiscale observations is limited due to the inherent complexity of capturing multi-scale eco-hydrological processes and the need for hierarchically nested scales of instrumentation to effectively investigate oasis-desert interactions and other heterogeneous land surface characteristics.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the high uncertainty of H estimation in irrigated farmland when using the TSEB model?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The high uncertainty of H estimation in irrigated farmland when using the TSEB model is caused by image classification errors that vary with vegetation abundance, the uncertainty of the TSEB model itself, and errors in the eddy covariance system, which result in canopy temperature overestimation under developing vegetation abundance.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the establishment of a sparse network of meteorological and flux observation stations affect data collection in oasis-desert interactions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The establishment of a sparse network of meteorological and flux observation stations enables the capture of multi-scale eco-hydrological processes, facilitating the investigation of oasis-desert interactions. This approach supports the collection of comprehensive data sets, leading to a better understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in these complex ecosystems.

Causal Consequence.Question: What is the impact of integrating ground-based measurements with remote sensing data on understanding oasis-desert systems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating ground-based measurements with remote sensing data improves the understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert systems. This combination allows for comprehensive coverage of multiscale observations, enhancing the ability to address challenges in eco-hydrological process upscaling and supporting ecological stability and socioeconomic development in arid regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the main objectives of establishing a hydrometeorological observation network in heterogeneous land surfaces, particularly in semi-arid regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The main objectives include understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems, which is crucial for achieving carbon peaking and carbon neutrality, supporting ecological security, and sustainable development of the oasis. The network aims to provide quantitative insights into oasis–desert interactions and address challenges such as ecological degradation in inland river basins.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to collect multiscale and multidisciplinary data in the context of eco-hydrological processes in heterogeneous surfaces?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Collecting multiscale and multidisciplinary data is crucial for addressing the grand challenge of upscaling eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces. It helps overcome the limitations posed by the poor availability of multiscale observations and allows for a comprehensive understanding of interactions between oasis and desert systems, leading to better management and sustainable development of these regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the intended outcomes of implementing high-resolution remote sensing techniques, such as thermal infrared cameras, in the monitoring of evapotranspiration in agricultural areas?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intended outcomes include accurately estimating surface fluxes like evaporation and transpiration in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas. High-resolution remote sensing techniques, such as thermal infrared cameras, help in separating soil and vegetation component temperatures, which are crucial for estimating energy balance and improving the accuracy of models like the two-source energy balance (TSEB) model.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What challenges arise in the collection and processing of multiscale observational data in oasis-desert systems, and how are these challenges addressed?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Challenges in collecting multiscale observational data include limited availability of multiscale observations, image classification errors, and the complexity of accurately measuring component temperatures in heterogeneous surfaces. These are addressed by deploying a hierarchically nested network of observation instruments, ensuring rigorous quality control through sensor calibration, and using advanced image classification methods to accurately separate soil and canopy pixels. Additionally, data processing involves careful calibration and validation against ground-based measurements to mitigate errors.

Enablement.Question: What instrumentation and hierarchical observation techniques enable the capture of multiscale eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert systems?
Enablement.Answer: Instruments for the oasis-desert system are arranged in hierarchically nested scales, including a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations. This setup captures multiscale eco-hydrological processes through intensive observation periods and continuous hydrometeorological observations.

Enablement.Question: How do technological advancements in thermal imaging enable better validation of evapotranspiration models in agricultural areas?
Enablement.Answer: The use of a high-resolution thermal infrared camera allows for the observation of soil and canopy component temperatures. These temperatures are used as inputs to models like the two-source energy balance (TSEB) model, enabling better validation of evaporation, transpiration, and evapotranspiration estimates by providing robust soil and vegetation component temperature calculations.

Enablement.Question: What data collection methods enable the understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Enablement.Answer: Data collection methods include the use of eddy covariance systems and scintillometers to acquire turbulent flux data, as well as automatic weather stations for hydrometeorological data collection. These stations observe variables like radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles, which are crucial for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be significant challenges in accurately estimating surface fluxes in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas using current data collection methods?
Expectation.Answer: Estimating surface fluxes in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas is challenging due to the incomplete energy balance closure with respect to available energy and the uncertainty in surface–air temperature difference. Errors can arise from determining the surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from the composite radiometric temperature, which affects the accuracy of the Two-Source Energy Balance (TSEB) model used for estimation.

Expectation.Question: Why is it expected that multiscale observations are necessary to understand eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces?
Expectation.Answer: Multiscale observations are necessary to understand eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces because these processes occur at different scales and require comprehensive data from various levels to be accurately captured and analyzed. The poor availability of such observations has hindered progress in this field, highlighting the need for a hierarchically nested observation system to address these complexities.

Expectation.Question: Why might the balance between oasis and desert systems be critical for achieving sustainable development in arid regions?
Expectation.Answer: Maintaining the balance between oasis and desert systems is critical for sustainable development in arid regions because these systems play a crucial role in ecological stability and agricultural productivity. Understanding the exchange of energy, water vapor, and carbon in these ecosystems is essential for ecological security and socioeconomic development, especially in areas like western China where oases are vital for supporting the majority of the population.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of the data collection methods used for capturing multi-scale eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert systems?
Judgmental.Answer: The data collection methods such as hierarchically nested scales and instrumentation like eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations are effective in capturing multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. Judgmental.Question: What is your assessment of the challenges faced in accurately estimating surface fluxes in arid agricultural areas using the two-source energy balance model?
Judgmental.Answer: The challenges in accurately estimating surface fluxes include the complex nature of the model, which requires parameters and observations difficult to obtain from satellite and ground-based data. Additionally, uncertainties in surface-air temperature differences and strong advective environments complicate the accuracy of the model. These factors can lead to overestimations of component temperatures, affecting the model's performance.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, how significant is the role of long-term observational datasets in understanding the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases?
Judgmental.Answer: Long-term observational datasets are crucial in understanding the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases. They provide essential data on energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, which are vital for recognizing oasis-desert interactions. Such datasets support the goals of carbon neutrality and sustainable development by offering insights into the fundamental characteristics of these ecosystems.

Assertion.Question: I don't quite understand how data quality control is ensured in the collection of meteorological data over a year.
Assertion.Answer: Quality control for meteorological data involves several steps: ensuring a complete daily data set with 144 data points (every 10 minutes), marking missing data with a specific value (-6999), removing duplicate records, deleting out-of-range data, and marking questionable data in red. Consistent formatting of date and time is also maintained.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how multiple datasets are integrated to study eco-hydrological processes in a region with heterogeneous surfaces.
Assertion.Answer: Integration of datasets for studying eco-hydrological processes involves the use of a multiscale observation system, combining data from eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, automatic meteorological stations, airborne remote sensing, and ground measurements. This system captures data across different scales and disciplines to address heterogeneity.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges faced in estimating evapotranspiration (ET) and its components in oasis-desert environments using remote sensing and ground-based measurements.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in estimating evapotranspiration (ET) and its components in oasis-desert environments include the heterogeneity of the surface, which affects the accuracy of one-source models, and the complexity of two-source models. Errors in component temperature estimation can arise from image classification errors, atmospheric conditions, and uncertainties in radiation measurements. The strong advective conditions in irrigated agricultural areas further complicate these estimations, making it difficult to achieve energy balance closure.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential datasets that could be integrated with existing multiscale datasets to enhance understanding of eco-hydrological processes in arid regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets that could be integrated include long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes from additional oasis-desert systems, satellite-derived vegetation indices, and high-resolution climate models. Incorporating datasets from other arid regions or extending existing datasets with more diverse vegetation and soil types could improve the understanding of eco-hydrological processes. Additionally, data from global carbon cycle studies and cryosphere interactions in the upper reaches could enhance insights into regional and global ecological dynamics.
